abstract_summ: One obstacle in observing disease emergence or elimination is understanding what influences noise in the data and how this fluctuates when near to zero cases.Finally, we propose a combined indicator for exponential growth in multiple data streams that may aid in developing an early warning system for future COVID-19 outbreaks.We have developed a methodology to monitor the standard type of data to inform whether a disease is approaching emergence or disease elimination.These results show that time series of disease incidence collected through ordinary surveillance activities may exhibit characteristic signatures prior to an outbreak, a phenomenon that may be quite general among infectious disease systems.Thereby, we can (a) quantify the effects of recent governmental measures to mitigating the disease spread, and (b) incorporate analogue change points to forecast future scenarios and case numbers.
title_summ: Early warning signals of malaria resurgence in Kericho, KenyaDynamical footprints enable detection of disease emergenceProspects for detecting early warning signals in discrete event sequence data: application to epidemiological incidence dataInferring COVID-19 spreading rates and potential change points for case number forecastsBayesian nowcasting with adjustment for delayed and incomplete reporting to estimate COVID-19 infections in the United StatesData-driven Identification of Number of Unreported Cases for COVID-19: Bounds and LimitationsAn Early Warning Approach to Monitor COVID-19 Activity with Multiple Digital Traces in Near Real-TimeInferring change points in the spread of COVID-19 reveals the effectiveness of interventions
title_abstract_phrases: One obstacle in observing disease emergence or elimination is understanding what influences noise in the data and how this fluctuates when near to zero cases.Inferring COVID-19 spreading rates and potential change points for case number forecastsAs COVID-19 is rapidly spreading across the globe, short-term modeling forecasts provide time-critical information for decisions on containment and mitigation strategies.Finally, we propose a combined indicator for exponential growth in multiple data streams that may aid in developing an early warning system for future COVID-19 outbreaks.Thereby, we can (a) quantify the effects of recent governmental measures to mitigating the disease spread, and (b) incorporate analogue change points to forecast future scenarios and case numbers.We have developed a methodology to monitor the standard type of data to inform whether a disease is approaching emergence or disease elimination.
